2509.13247__2509.13247_fig1p1_dc0e30eae9.label: fig:cdcx_arbitrary
descriptions: Arbitrary-length logical constant-depth CNOT ladder. A ⊕ on a measured data bit is flipped if the sum (modulo 2) of the measured ancilla bits above it with an ⊕ is 1. The qubits with/without a Hadamard applied at the start are ancilla/data qubits, respectively.

2509.13247__2509.13247_fig1p1_221364ed01.label: fig:placeholder
descriptions: L=2 Many-hypercube state preparation circuit. The five pairs of qubits are initialized to the logical |00⟩_L state of the [[4, 2, 2]] code (Equation <ref>).

2509.13247__2509.13247_fig1p1_d51f40897f.label: fig:cdcx_unencoded
descriptions:
Logical circuit for a 5 CNOT, constant-depth CNOT-ladder on a 4×2 grid of qubits. 
The brackets surround qubits on the same row. 
The dashed lines separate the circuit into three parts: 
the first creates a Bell pair between the ancilla row and the second data row, 
the second consists of the CNOTs from the first two sections of the original circuit (Figure <ref>) being executed in parallel, 
and the third consists of the final CNOT from the original circuit, measurement, and classical correction.

2509.04761__2509.04761_fig1p1_d08a1a6349.label: fig:decompos
descriptions: Example of how redundant CX pairs appear and how to remove them. (a) will decompose a multi-qubit controlled operator into RCCX gates (illustrated as CCX gates in the figure) and a single controlled-U gate. (b) can eliminate redundant control operations depending on the states of qubits. (c) Redundant CX pairs can be removed once they are identified as redundant.

2504.19827__2504.19827_fig1p1_3759320e17.label: fig:kronecker
descriptions:
Quantum circuit for the Kronecker delta operation for two r-qubit registers |a⟩ and |b⟩.
		The CNOT^⊗ r represents r parallel CNOT gates while the center gate is an r-qubit controlled NOT gate with r-2 hidden ancilla qubits.

2407.18347__2407.18347_fig1p1_c20c2b9089.label: fig:dirichlet lcu circuit
descriptions: Quantum circuit for LCU of second derivative operator with boundary conditions on a simply or non-simply connected domain in d-dimensions using low-order stencil ℒ^(BC). The subnormalization 4d results from λ = 4 for the 3 point stencil, which we then combine d times. Here we use the notation prep as the unitary which prepares the finite difference coefficients on the stencil register and D_d as the unitary which prepares the equal superposition over d states on the dim register where S^j_l refers to the modular increment-by-j operator in direction l. We use the ⊘ convention to mean controlled over every state. Appending an additional register of log(η) qubits and selecting over shift operators both in dimension and particle indices will implement the η-particle Laplacian over d-dimensions.

2407.18347__2407.18347_fig1p1_08ff024de3.label: fig:enter-label
descriptions: Quantum circuit to implement (2(λ + β), m+l)-block encoding of a finite difference approximation to the differential operator with arbitrary boundary conditions. dom is an oracle which marks each point |x⟩ in the [N^d] with a two-bit label |x⟩|b_0,b_1⟩, with '00' indicating interior points, '01' indicating boundary points and '10' indicating exterior points. Here, U_L is a block encoding of the differential operator defined with periodic boundary conditions on [0,L]^d in matrix form and U_B is a block encoding of the Dirichlet, Neumann, or Robin boundary condition in matrix form.  U_f implements the unitary transformation |b_0,b_1⟩→ (-1)^b_0⊕ b_1|b_0,b_1⟩ and U_f' implements |b_0,b_1⟩→ (-1)^b_0⊕ 1 ⊕ b_1|b_0,b_1⟩, to cause the summed operators to be projected onto the appropriate boundary modes. Because dom is not restricted to marking points that correspond to a domain with orthogonal boundary faces, this procedure can be used to implement a broad family of boundary conditions.

2502.06463__2502.06463_fig1p1_c46d791464.label: fig:basecircuitForwardEvolution

descriptions: The XX-stabilizer measurement between a pair of successive rows, shown for the 3× 3 Bacon-Shor code. The top panel shows the circuit involving the 2× 5=10 extended data qubits that make up two successive rows of a 3× 3 Bacon-Shor code, with one ancillary qubit and one flag qubit (bottom qubits). The bottom panel shows the order in which the extended data qubits are coupled via the CNOTs to the ancillary qubit to assure fault-tolerance properties (see Sec. <ref>). The blue circles are the data qubits; the yellow ones are the coupling ancillas; the arrows indicate the order in which the ancillary qubit is coupled to the extended data qubits in the two rows.

2503.22108__2503.22108_fig1p1_35b0334b12.label: fig:HST
descriptions: Single-logical-qubit gadget implementing the gate G=H, S, or T. |Ψ⟩ is the incoming state on which G is to be applied. For G=H, |Φ⟩=|+⟩_L, g_1 is the identity, and g_2=X; for G=S, |Φ⟩=|Φ_S⟩, g_1=H, and g_2=Y=XZ; for G=T, |Φ⟩=|Φ_T⟩, g_1=H, and g_2=SX. The gate g_2 is applied, conditioned on the outcome of the X measurement. We note that the X and Z contained in the g_2s do not need to be applied physically; see the main text.

2507.08746__2507.08746_fig1p1_785d827156.label: QFT
descriptions: Quantum circuit designed to carry out the Fourier Transform in the unary basis. Single-qubit operations are phase gates, while vertical connections represent RBS gates with a rotation angle of π/4. This arrangement mirrors the classical FFT butterfly structure by replacing each radix-2 operation with a phase gate followed by an RBS gate. The amplitudes in the input state vector |x⟩=∑_i=0^7x_i|e_i⟩ properly permuted and encoded in the unary basis, are transformed into the desired output state.

The “IS” gate can be any gate chosen to prepare the initial gate of the latent system. The “AC” gate is the chosen Ansatz circuit. The observed register is reset to the |0⟩ state after each measurement.

descriptions: Quantum circuit for incrementing an integer j=j_1j_2⋯ j_m by 1 to j+1, where each qubit in the right diagram represents a binary digit j_l of j. The binary decomposition j=j_1 2^m-1+j_2 2^m-2 +j_m 2^0 of the integer j is used.

2411.05058__2411.05058_fig1p1_ab4a882a28.label: fig:uid
descriptions: Circuit identity for ∑_v=0^M-1 |v⟩⟨v| ⊗T̂^v showing how a linear combination of sequentially increasing powers of unitary T̂ <cit.> can be efficiently factorized.

2411.05058__2411.05058_fig1p1_809c365b5b.label: fig:stm_proj_circ
descriptions: Symmetry group transform quantum circuit for the cyclic group ℤ_8.

2411.05058__2411.05058_fig1p1_6d1b10d2b0.label: fig:s2_proj_circ
descriptions: S_2 symmetry projection circuit, acting on two system registers |Ψ⟩_0 and |Ψ⟩_1 of m qubits each and one ancilla qubit |Γ⟩_0. Comparing with Fig. <ref>, the QCT is reduced to a Hadamard gate, and the  operation is implemented by an identity (no operation) and a controlled SWAP in the above. In this case, T_ GSA of the group S_2 reduces to the familiar SWAP test on the two system registers. This circuit can be used to project an arbitrary initial state on two system registers to their symmetric and anti-symmetric sectors.

2411.05058__2411.05058_fig1p1_6d1129e1ed.label: Fig2:tgsa+qpe
descriptions: Circuit for symmetry-adapted quantum phase estimation, where the first two registers carry information of the irreps and the quantum state ψ of our many-body system, while the last register with n qubits is the ancilla used for QPE. The input state ψ is first decomposed into a coherent superposition of all irreps by T̂_ GSA, and then a QPE or any other quantum subroutine can be applied to transform all irrep sectors of the quantum state simultaneously. The eigen energies and the irreps of quantum states will be stored in the first and the last register, where measurement (or amplitude amplification, not shown) can be performed to estimate the energies of states within a desired irrep.

2411.05058__2411.05058_fig1p1_653dcfc8b8.label: fig:stm_proj_circAppendix
descriptions: Symmetry group transform for the cyclic group ℤ_8, using an explicit projection circuit. Since the input state on the ancilla is the trivial irrep |0⟩_0 |0⟩_1 |0⟩_2, the QFT in Fig. <ref> can be simply replaced by a Hadamard transform in the above.

2402.10265__2402.10265_fig1p1_e9b5b52703.label: fig:ancilla_prep
descriptions: Circuit that sends all ancillas (A_1, A_2, and A_3 beginning in the state |0⟩) to the state |1⟩ if the physical qubits (P_1 and P_2) are in the state |0⟩, and leaves them alone otherwise. The upper diagram shows the connectivity of the qubits on the hardware and the lower shows the circuit applied to these qubits.

2509.05924__2509.05924_fig1p1_75e7ea5309.label: fig:classification_flow
descriptions: Classification flow. System+ancillas processed by U(Θ); IC measurement outcomes feed a classical head that outputs the learned witness.

2508.04536__2508.04536_fig1p1_9703365297.label: circ
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol. The segment before the red dashed line represents the initial preparation of two entangled qubit pairs. The segment after the line illustrates the entanglement swap operation, performed by measuring one qubit from each pair in an entangled basis–specifically, the Bell basis in this case.

2508.04536__2508.04536_fig1p1_f8f24799ab.label: S
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol between two partially entangled |η_m⟩,|η_p⟩ states, outputting an entangled state which is either |η_m+p⟩ or |η_m-p⟩. This setup of gates is what we will from now on refer to as the S operator, that acts upon four qubits and outputs two qubits. Whether the output is |η_m+p⟩ or |η_m-p⟩ can be determined by the measurements of second and third qubits. As we are not interested in what is the final state of a specific entanglement swap iteration, but rather in the possible states generated by it and its probabilities, we will not use that information.

2508.04536__2508.04536_fig1p1_772984abcf.label: multipartido
descriptions: Schematic of the entanglement swapping protocol between two partially entangled states |ξ_m⟩,|η_p⟩, outputting an entangled state which is either |ξ_m+p⟩ or |ξ_m-p⟩. It is clear that only one qubit from |ξ_m⟩ participates in the protocol.

2508.04536__2508.04536_fig1p1_e9aa1ba401.label: star
descriptions: Schematic of a entanglement swapping protocol intended to create a GHZ state.

descriptions: QAOA circuit with variational parameters γ, β and Hamiltonians H_C and H_M. The blue section highlights a single QAOA layer which is repeated p times with individual parameters. A final measurement of ⟨ H_C⟩ is used to classically optimize γ and β. After several iterations of that procedure, the circuit prepares the desired ground state of H_C.
